text_image_relationship.layout_style: Two narrow columns of verse text are separated at mid-page by two equal-sized rectangular miniatures set side by side. Wide outer and lower margins remain blank. A large red—and blue—ornamental initial with pen flourish begins the first column above the first miniature. Text resumes above, between, and below the paired scenes without wrapping around them.

text_content.language: Middle High German with Latin captions
text_content.script_style: Gothic textura quadrata in dark brown ink, professional book hand with red rubrication and occasional blue pen flourishes; frequent use of standard medieval abbreviations and ligatures

color_scheme.color_usage: Gold leaf is reserved for crowns and haloes, emphasizing royal and divine status. Deep ultramarine blue backgrounds denote the second scene’s elevated importance, while the first scene’s crimson ground signals narrative continuity. Figures are left in white lead-white gown underdrawn in brown ink; vermilion and white highlights model drapery folds. Red and blue rubricated initials alternate to mark textual divisions. Pigments remain well-preserved with minimal darkening or flaking.

features: Central balance created by mirrored framing devices
Rectangular borders with white inner fillet unify both scenes
Each scene contained entirely within its own niche
Horizontal visual axis linking the two miniatures

decorative_elements: Large red and blue historiated initial with pen flourish
Rectangular gilt frames around each miniature
Red-on-white scroll banners bearing Latin captions
Minor blue and red penwork flourishes in margins

drawing_technique.line_style: Fine, even brown-ink outlines with uniform width; confident contour drawing
drawing_technique.shading_method: Flat areas of color with minimal tonal gradation, white lead highlights create slight volume in drapery
drawing_technique.perspective_handling: Hierarchical scaling without geometric perspective; shallow stage-like depth indicated by slight overlapping of figures

scene_relationships.subject: Queen of Sheba dispatches envoys before her to Solomon
scene_relationships.relationship_to_next: Precedes her personal audience in the following scene
visual_connections: Red background carried into adjacent panel’s border
Latin scroll banners in identical style and placement
Figures in left panel oriented to the right toward the next scene
Consistent frame design uniting both images
White-clad robes echo in the second panel

scene_relationships.subject: Personal meeting of the Queen of Sheba with King Solomon and his entourage
visual_connections: Gold crown motif repeated on both royal figures
Donkey motif carries over from journey in first scene
Banners above each scene use the same red-lettering style
Figures face leftward, visually linking back to initial panel
Framing fillet of white and gold is identical

visual_continuity: Identical rectangular gilt frames around each scene
Uniform brown-ink outlines and underdrawing throughout
Gold leaf applied sparingly to crowns and haloes
Latin inscription scroll banners above both panels
Consistent figure proportions and hierarchical scaling
Alternating red and blue backgrounds for narrative emphasis
Matching white lead-white robes on principal figures

content_theme.scene_description: The miniature group comprises two narrative scenes illustrating the Queen of Sheba’s embassy to Solomon. In the left panel (seven figures), a crowned female meanwhile unseen is represented only by her envoys: eight white-robed courtiers and a donkey bearing gifts stand before a vermilion field. The group gestures toward a circular mandorla above, containing a seated bearded figure—God the Father or Solomon in divine wisdom—handing a scroll to an attendant. Figures wear long tunics with simple hems and narrow belts; their gestures and gazes are directed horizontally toward the next panel. In the right panel, the Queen herself, crowned and haloed, rides a laden donkey across a deep ultramarine ground. She holds a tall ewer as a gift. Opposite her stand Solomon and two armored retainers beneath a stylized city façade. Solomon wears a crown and long mantle edged in gold, bearing a scepter; his soldiers carry lances and shields striped black and white. Spatially, the donkey overlaps the margin of Solomon’s niche to suggest continuity. The two scenes are unified by identical framing, matching scroll labels, and reciprocal directional gazes, creating a coherent left-to-right visual narrative.

secular: Queen of Sheba: crowned, haloed, white lead-white gown, gold-edged mantle, seated on donkey
Solomon: crowned, long gold-edged mantle, scepter in right hand
Envoys and courtiers: white tunics, narrow belts, expressive gestures
Armored retainers: mail coifs, lances, striped shields

objects: Donkey bearing pack saddle and cloth bundles
Tall ewer held by the Queen
architectural: Simplified city façade with domed towers behind Solomon

technical_features.material: Premium calf vellum, smooth parchment with even thickness, ruled in plummet for text and image registers
technical_features.preservation_condition: Overall excellent: pigments retain brightness, minor flaking of vermilion at edges, slight cockling in lower margin, no significant tears or stains
notable_physical_characteristics: Raised gesso under gold leaf in crowns and haloes
Underdrawing visible in brown ink underlayer
Diagonal ruling lines faintly discernible beneath text
Red lead pricks mark margin frames

analysis.scholarly_interpretation: This bifoliate illumination, likely produced in a Franco-Flemish workshop circa 1330–1350, reveals the synthesis of High Gothic pictorial conventions with didactic biblical narrative. The choice of ultramarine and vermilion grounds, paired with lavish gold leaf on regalia, underscores the dual themes of divine wisdom and royal authority. The symmetrical arrangement of two contiguous miniatures, framed identically and interlinked by directional gazes and matching scroll banners, exemplifies a controlled compositional balance characteristic of Parisian ateliers influenced by the so-called “Rayonnant” aesthetic. The script—a professional Gothic textura quadrata with red and blue rubrication—suggests a commissioned work for an educated audience, perhaps a monastery or university, intended to reinforce moral teachings through memorable visual exempla. Iconographically, the depiction of the Queen of Sheba’s embassy to Solomon draws on typological tradition, aligning her offerings and testimony with the receipt of divine wisdom, thereby echoing contemporary theological exegesis on prophecy and royal virtue. Comparatively, the fine underdrawing and gesso-raised gold link this manuscript to the Psalter of Queen Jeanne of Navarre (Bibliothèque nationale de France, ms. lat. 115), while the clear line and color separations anticipate innovations in Netherlandish illumination. Overall, the page offers a compelling testimony to collaborative workshop practices and to the continued evolution of narrative clarity and ornamental richness in mid-14th-century book arts.
